factoid: The man with braces said "Another petitioner."
The man with braces told Rostóv to come later.
The man with braces said that Rostóv will be coming out directly.
The man with braces said that they must go.
Rostóv turned and was about to go.
The man with braces stopped Rostóv.
The man with braces asked whom Rostóv came from.
The man with braces asked who Rostóv was.
Rostóv answered that he comes from Major Denísov.
Rostóv answered that he is Lieutenant Count Rostóv.
The man with braces said "What audacity! Hand it in through your commander. And go along with you... go."
The valet handed Rostóv a uniform and Rostóv put it on.
Rostóv went back into the hall.
Rostóv noticed that in the porch there were many officers and generals in full parade uniform.
Rostóv had to pass those officers and generals.
Rostóv cursed his temerity.
Rostóv's heart sank at the thought of finding himself face to face with the Emperor.
Rostóv feared being put to shame and arrested in the presence of the Emperor.
Rostóv became fully aware of the impropriety of his conduct.
Rostóv repented his conduct.
Rostóv was making his way out of the house through the brilliant suite.
A familiar voice called Rostóv.
A hand detained Rostóv.
The deep voice asked Rostóv what he was doing here in civilian dress.
The voice belonged to a cavalry general.
The cavalry general had obtained the Emperor’s special favor during this campaign.
The cavalry general had formerly commanded the division in which Rostóv was serving.
Rostóv began justifying himself to the cavalry general.
Rostóv saw the cavalry general's kindly, jocular face.
Rostóv took the cavalry general aside.
Rostóv told the cavalry general the whole affair in an excited voice.
Rostóv asked the cavalry general to intercede for Major Denísov.
The cavalry general knew Major Denísov.
The cavalry general shook his head gravely after hearing Rostóv.
The cavalry general said "I'm sorry, sorry for that fine fellow. Give me the letter."
Rostóv handed the cavalry general the letter.
Rostóv finished explaining Denísov's case to the cavalry general.
Hasty steps and jingling of spurs were heard on the stairs.
The cavalry general left Rostóv and went to the porch.
The gentlemen of the Emperor’s suite ran down the stairs and went to their horses.
Hayne, the groom who had been at Austerlitz, led up the Emperor’s horse.
A faint creak of a footstep was heard on the stairs.
Rostóv recognized the footstep immediately.
Rostóv went close to the porch with some inquisitive civilians.
Rostóv saw the Emperor again after two years.
Rostóv saw the Emperor's face, look, step, and union of majesty and mildness.
Rostóv felt enthusiasm and love for his sovereign again.
Rostóv was wearing the uniform of the Preobrazhénsk regiment.
The uniform included white chamois-leather breeches and high boots.
Rostóv was wearing a star that he did not know was the Légion d’honneur star.
The Emperor came out into the porch.
The Emperor put on his gloves.
The Emperor carried his hat under his arm.
The Emperor stopped and looked around.
The Emperor brightened everything around by his glance.
The Emperor spoke a few words to some of the generals.
The Emperor recognized the former commander of Rostóv’s division.
The Emperor smiled and beckoned to Rostóv.
The suite drew back.
Rostóv saw the cavalry general talking for some time to the Emperor.
The Emperor said a few words to the cavalry general.
The Emperor took a step toward his horse.
The crowd of suite members and street gazers moved nearer to the Emperor.
The Emperor stopped beside his horse with his hand on the saddle.
The Emperor turned to the cavalry general.
The Emperor said "I cannot do it, General. I cannot, because the law is stronger than I."
The Emperor raised his foot to the stirrup.
The cavalry general bowed his head respectfully.
The Emperor mounted his horse and rode down the street at a gallop.
Rostóv ran after the Emperor with the crowd.
The Emperor rode to the square.
In the square a battalion of the Preobrazhénsk regiment stood on the right.
In the square a battalion of the French Guards stood on the left wearing bearskin caps.
